content: Powdery mildew is one of the most widespread and easily recognized plant diseases. It appears as a superficial white or gray powdery growth on leaves, stems, flowers, and fruits of various plants. The disease is caused by many specialized races of fungal species in the genera Erysiphe, Microsphaera, Phyllactinia, Podosphaera, Sphaerotheca, and Uncinula. Almost all plants can be affected, including many vegetables, fruits, and ornamentals.

Treatment for Powdery Mildew: Remove and destroy all infected plant parts. Improve air circulation by thinning and pruning. Avoid overhead watering to keep foliage dry. Apply sulfur fungicides to prevent infection on susceptible plants. Neem oil, potassium bicarbonate, and milk solutions (1:10 with water) can be effective organic treatments. For severe cases, use appropriate fungicides labeled for powdery mildew.

Blight is a general term for a variety of plant diseases that can affect crops and ornamental plants. Early blight and late blight are two common forms affecting tomatoes and potatoes. Late blight, caused by Phytophthora infestans, is especially destructive and was responsible for the Irish potato famine. Symptoms include water-soaked spots on leaves that quickly turn brown, white fuzzy growth on the underside of leaves in humid conditions, and rapid plant collapse.

Treatment for Blight: Practice crop rotation and plant resistant varieties. Remove and destroy all infected plant material. Ensure adequate spacing for proper air circulation. Apply copper-based fungicides as a preventative measure. For organic gardens, copper treatments and bacillus subtilis products can help. Apply treatments early when conditions favor disease development (humid, wet weather). Clean all garden tools thoroughly when moving between plants.

Leaf spot diseases are caused by various fungi and bacteria that result in spots on foliage. The spots can vary in size and color depending on the pathogen, plant affected, and stage of development. Common leaf spot fungal diseases include Septoria, Cercospora, and Alternaria leaf spots. Most leaf spot diseases initially cause small, water-soaked lesions that enlarge and change color to tan, brown, or black. Severe infections can cause defoliation.

Treatment for Leaf Spot Diseases: Remove and destroy fallen leaves and infected plant parts. Avoid overhead watering and water at the base of plants. Ensure proper spacing for adequate air circulation. Apply fungicides labeled for leaf spot diseases when symptoms first appear. Copper-based fungicides and neem oil can be effective for organic gardening. For bacterial leaf spots, copper bactericides may be helpful. Practice crop rotation to prevent disease buildup in the soil.

Apple scab is a serious disease of apples and ornamental crabapples, caused by the fungus Venturia inaequalis. It manifests as olive-green to brown or black spots on leaves and fruits. Infected leaves may drop prematurely, and severely affected fruits develop cracks that allow secondary infection. The fungus overwinters in fallen leaves and infects new growth in spring during wet periods.

Treatment for Apple Scab: Plant resistant apple varieties when possible. Rake and destroy fallen leaves to reduce the primary inoculum. Prune trees to improve air circulation and speed drying of foliage. Apply fungicides starting at bud break until petal fall, especially during wet periods. Organic options include sulfur sprays before bloom and throughout the growing season as needed. Maintain tree vigor through proper nutrition and watering practices.

Black spot is the most serious disease of roses caused by the fungus Diplocarpon rosae. It appears as black spots with fringed margins on the upper surface of leaves, eventually causing yellowing and premature leaf drop. Repeated defoliation weakens plants, reduces flowering, and makes them more susceptible to other stresses. The disease is favored by humid conditions and temperatures between 65°F and 85°F.

Treatment for Black Spot on Roses: Select resistant rose varieties for new plantings. Remove and destroy all infected leaves, both on the plant and on the ground. Prune to increase air circulation and avoid wetting the foliage when watering. Apply fungicides preventatively before symptoms appear in spring. Organic options include neem oil, sulfur, and potassium bicarbonate. For chemical control, apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil, myclobutanil, or propiconazole according to label instructions.

Several diseases cause leaf spots on tomatoes, including early blight (Alternaria solani), Septoria leaf spot (Septoria lycopersici), and bacterial spot (Xanthomonas spp.). Early blight appears as dark brown spots with concentric rings, Septoria leaf spot causes small circular spots with dark borders and gray centers, and bacterial spot creates small, dark, greasy-looking spots. All can significantly reduce yields by defoliating plants.

Treatment for Tomato Leaf Spot Diseases: Rotate crops, avoiding planting tomatoes, potatoes, eggplants, or peppers in the same location for 3-4 years. Use mulch to prevent soil splash onto lower leaves. Remove lower leaves showing symptoms and destroy them. Stake or cage plants to improve air circulation. For fungal leaf spots, apply copper-based fungicides or chlorothalonil at first sign of disease and continue on a 7-10 day schedule in wet weather. For bacterial leaf spots, copper-based bactericides can provide some control.

Rust diseases are caused by many different species of fungi in the order Pucciniales. They appear as rusty, orange, yellow, or brown pustules on leaves, stems, and sometimes fruits. Each rust fungus is specific to certain host plants. Common examples include cedar-apple rust, rose rust, hollyhock rust, and geranium rust. The pustules release spores that can be spread by wind to infect other plants.

Treatment for Rust Diseases: Plant resistant varieties when available. For cedar-apple rust, separate alternate hosts (cedar/juniper trees and apple/crabapple trees) by at least 300 feet. Remove and destroy infected plant parts. Apply preventative fungicides in early spring before symptoms appear. For light infections, remove and destroy affected leaves. For organic control, sulfur fungicides can be effective. Improve air circulation around plants and avoid overhead watering.

Downy mildew is a plant disease caused by oomycetes (water molds) in the family Peronosporaceae. It affects many plants including grapes, cucurbits, lettuce, and ornamentals. Symptoms include yellow to brown patches on the upper leaf surface and fuzzy, grayish-white to purple growth on the lower surface. Unlike powdery mildew, it requires moist conditions to develop and spreads rapidly in cool, wet weather.

Treatment for Downy Mildew: Plant resistant varieties when available. Avoid overhead irrigation and water early in the day so leaves can dry. Space plants properly to promote air circulation. Apply preventative fungicides before symptoms appear when conditions favor disease development. For organic gardens, copper fungicides can provide some protection. Remove and destroy infected plant material. In greenhouses, reduce humidity and improve air circulation.
